Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of Zernike Phase Contrast For Biological Electron Microscopy
Award.AbstractNarration: This Major Research Instrumentation award funds the development of a novel Zernike laser phase plate for cryo-TEM at University of California-Berkeley. In Zernike phase contrast microscopy, a quarter-wave plate in the focal plane of the object lens shifts the phase of the undiffracted part of the beam to provide optimal conversion of phase modulations into image contrast. The new laser phase plate will allow researchers to operate TEMs in an optimal phase-contrast mode for indefinite periods of time. Compared with defocused bright field method, the contrast in the imaging of biological macromolecules and supramolecular structures could be as much as ten times greater. Moreover, the possibility to make a tiny focus and the possibility to tune it optically makes it possible to image lower spatial frequencies and offers greater flexibility than with microfabricated phase plates. This new phase contrast system will be used to investigate problems in molecular and cell biology that are out of the reach of existing techniques in electron microscopy, x-ray crystallography, or multi-dimensional NMR spectroscopy. Finally, we anticipate additional applications in fundamental physics, e.g., developing an optical dipole trap for atoms and molecules of almost any species, with the ability to trap even room-temperature samples. The results of the development effort will be broadly disseminated through abstracts and peer reviewed publications, as well as by active participation of students and faculty at professional meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transmission electron microsscopes (TEMs) can reach extremely high magnifications and are applied in biology, materials science and other fields. For many specimens (e.g., in molecular biology), however, they suffer from a lack of contrast, as electrons pass many specimens nearly uninhibited. The analogous problem in light microscopy has been solved in the 1940ies. Even light that is not absorbed may still be phase-shifted by the structure of the specimen. Phase shifts are invisible to the eye, but Frits Zernike developed a method of converting them into visible contrast. The method is based on interference between light that was phase-shifted by the specimen and light that was not. It requires a "phase plate" that gives an extra phase shift of 90 degrees to the light that hasn't been shifted by the specimen. This method should equally be applicable to electron microscopy. Unfortunately, however, it has proved hard to find a reliable way to make an electron phase plate that does not distort the beam (and thus the image). 

In this project, we develp a phase plate based on the interaction between electrons and laser beams. Because it does not require insertion of a material object into the electron stream, it avoids many of the beam distortion and lifetime issues of other designs.

We have overcome major hurdles on the way to developing phase contrast for electron microscopy, and gave pioneering demonstrations of the underlying physics. On the conceptual front, we resolved the theoretical problem of laser-induced electron phase shift in the laser phase plate, where usual ponderomotive approximation breaks down as electrons traverse a tightly focused laser beam, and treatment based on second-order approximation of the quasiclassical phase shift is needed. A paper describing this derivation is in preparation. 

On the experimental front, the investigators constructed means to generate the requisite laser intensity and focusing. They demonstrated optical cavities with both high numerical aperture (0.15) and high finesse (>20,000) at 1064 nm wavelength. They invented a method of non-resonant intensity enhancement in waveguides, and demonstrated conversion of a 14 W CO2 laser beam to zero order Bessel beams with a central spot radius of about 50 micrometers (verified using a microbolometer).

Towards systems integration, a special FEI Titan 80-300 keV TEM provides mechanical access for the laser phase plate and additional electron optics that matches the size of the undiffracted electron beam to the size of the laser focus. An insertion module has been built for integration of the optical system into the TEM. Co-I Bob Glaeser has already demonstrated phase-contrast imaging using an alternative "Tulip" phase plate, based on microfabrication. 

Towards applications, the investigators established collaborations with users at the National Center for Electron Microscopy, Stanford, as well as TEM-related industrial companies in California. The project has provided cross-disciplinary training to graduate students and postdocs; the first postdoc, Michelle Xu, is now Photonics Engineer at Intel Corporation. The methods developed will have broad applicability on interferometry with electrons, optical dipole trapping of atoms and molecules, and perhaps even quantum information.

Under the new timeline, the optical module is expected to be operational in the optical lab by July 2016 and integration into the Titan TEM will be complete by the end of 2016. It will then be made available for users to investigate problems in molecular and cell biology that are out of the reach of existing techniques in electron microscopy, x-ray crystallography, or multi-dimensional NMR spectroscopy.
